awd_titl_txt: Reusing Data Efficiently for Iterative and Integrative Inference
awd_abstract_narration:
Drawing knowledge and reproducible results from complex data drives a broad range of scientific disciplines. From a statistical viewpoint, model selection and inference are the two fundamental tasks, the latter often pursued only after models are chosen through data-driven procedures. Naively using the same data for both tasks creates complicated correlations between the selected models and their inferential properties, which inevitably affects the reproducibility of findings from these models. The investigator develops methods for reusing data from selection to compensate for these correlations while not squandering away information from the full data. Finding immediate use in biomedical problems, observational studies in the behavioral sciences, and engineering applications, the methods will aid discoveries even when analyses rely on scarce samples. This research has a broader outreach component in creating opportunities for interdisciplinary engagement, training statisticians, and contributing to a new graduate curriculum.

The project is geared towards efficient and reproducible inference through a reuse of data from the model selection steps.  Combining ideas from convex optimization, probability theory, and statistical learning, the project seeks solutions for two main thrusts. In the first thrust, the investigator develops methods to integrate fresh samples available at a later point in time with information from selection. This workflow is realized in modern applications such as online streaming of data, which demand iterative inference on the fly. In the second thrust, the investigator explores integrative inference by combining selected models from different batches or splits or sources of data. Aggregating inference from multiple sources through a reuse of samples will have the potential for new discoveries that any single dataset may fail to report due to a lack of power.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Empirical studies involve multiple stages, often beginning with the identification of promising findings based on preliminary (pilot) data. As additional observations become available, researchers face the challenge of combining this new data with the pilot data to make confirmatory inference about these promising findings. On the one hand, a naive approach that directly combines the two datasets overlooks the over-optimism due to the selection process, often leading to highly misleading conclusions. On the other hand, traditional methods like data splitting, which rely solely on the new data for inference, are inefficient because they discard the pilot data entirely during the inferential stages of the study. This approach of first identifying promising findings and then seeking inference for the selected findings is widespread across the empirical sciences, including biomedical research, survey studies, and clinical trials. The need to efficiently reuse pilot data becomes even more pressing in studies where collecting large amounts of new data at any stage is time-consuming, costly, or both.

 

The outcomes of this project make important contributions to the development of novel methodologies, theories, and algorithms that enable the efficient reuse of data from the selection stages of empirical studies, enabling valid and efficient confirmatory inference. Specifically, two types of inferential procedures are developed: (i) iterative inference, where pilot data from an earlier selection stage is combined with new samples from a later stage for inference, and (ii) integrative inference, where data from multiple selection stages, conducted at the same time, are aggregated for inference using the full dataset. These advances help restore the validity of inference by properly accounting for the selection process, while enhancing inferential efficiency—such as producing shorter confidence intervals—compared to traditional splitting-based techniques. The improvement in efficiency results from the new methods' ability to combine data employed during selection with new data or validation data, thereby utilizing all available samples for inference rather than just a subsample of the full data.

 

The research outcomes of this project have applications across various scientific domains, including neuroscience, clinical trials, and genetics. Some of these applications in biomedical research are being actively pursued by the PI and her collaborators as part of ongoing work. The project has resulted in several published and accepted articles in leading journals in Statistics and Machine Learning, including the Annals of Statistics, Journal of the American Statistical Association, Biometrika, Biometrics, Journal of Machine Learning Research, and the Annals of Applied Statistics. The PI has delivered over 15 presentations at both domestic and international forums to disseminate the findings from this project and continues to actively share the work. This project has also facilitated the PI in establishing collaborations within her institution and with multiple institutions nationwide. 


As part of the educational and outreach component of the project, the support has been instrumental in training both undergraduate and graduate students at the PI’s institution. Notably, the PI has trained ten undergraduate students in cutting-edge research through a partnership with the Undergraduate Research Program in Statistics (URPS) at her institution. Over the past two years, the PI has also mentored diverse groups of undergraduate students as part of the Big Data Summer Institute (BDSI), a six-week long summer program at the University of Michigan. Through this program, the PI has provided students with valuable research experience drawn from ideas developed in this project while actively supporting their career growth in STEM fields. Additionally, the project has contributed to the development of the PhD theses of three graduate students and has involved two additional graduate students in the PI’s research.
